summary:
Proxies and load balancers are essential components in modern web architecture, facilitating communication between clients and servers while enhancing security and performance. Proxies can be categorized into forward proxies, which act on behalf of clients to access servers, and reverse proxies, which serve as intermediaries that hide the destination servers from clients. Forward proxies can help bypass restrictions and enforce access controls, while reverse proxies, including load balancers, manage incoming traffic to multiple servers, ensuring efficient resource utilization and high availability. Load balancers distribute user requests across several servers using various algorithms, such as round robin and least connections, to optimize performance and reliability.

The implementation of load balancers can be complex, involving considerations of different layers (Layer 4 and Layer 7) that dictate how requests are processed. Layer 4 load balancers operate at the transport layer and are faster but less flexible, while Layer 7 load balancers function at the application layer, allowing for more intelligent routing based on request content. To prevent single points of failure, multiple load balancers can be deployed, ensuring continuous service availability. Understanding these concepts is crucial for developers and system designers aiming to build scalable and resilient applications.
learning_objectives: After studying this, you will understand the differences between forward and reverse proxies.
You will learn how load balancers work and their importance in managing server traffic.
You will be able to identify various traffic distribution algorithms and their applications.
